nodes.label: access control
nodes.definition: means to ensure that access to assets is authorized and restricted based on business and security requirements (3.56)

nodes.label: attack
nodes.definition: attempt to destroy, expose, alter, disable, steal or gain unauthorized access to or make unauthorized use of an asset

nodes.label: audit
nodes.definition: systematic, independent and documented process (3.54) for obtaining audit evidence and evaluating it objectively to determine the extent to which the audit criteria are fulfilled
notes: An audit can be an internal audit (first party) or an external audit (second party or third party), and it can be a combined audit (combining two or more disciplines). | An internal audit is conducted by the organization itself, or by an external party on its behalf. | "Audit evidence" and "audit criteria" are defined in ISO 19011.

nodes.label: audit scope
nodes.definition: extent and boundaries of an audit (3.3)

nodes.label: authentication
nodes.definition: provision of assurance that a claimed characteristic of an entity is correct

nodes.label: authenticity
nodes.definition: property that an entity is what it claims to be

nodes.label: availability
nodes.definition: property of being accessible and usable on demand by an authorized entity

nodes.label: base measure
nodes.definition: measure (3.42) defined in terms of an attribute and the method for quantifying it
notes: A base measure is functionally independent of other measures.

nodes.label: competence
nodes.definition: ability to apply knowledge and skills to achieve intended results

nodes.label: confidentiality
nodes.definition: property that information is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized individuals, entities, or processes (3.54)

nodes.label: conformity
nodes.definition: fulfilment of a requirement (3.56)

nodes.label: consequence
nodes.definition: outcome of an event (3.21) affecting objectives (3.49)
notes: An event can lead to a range of consequences. | A consequence can be certain or uncertain and, in the context of information security, is usually negative. | Consequences can be expressed qualitatively or quantitatively. | Initial consequences can escalate through knock-on effects.

nodes.label: continual improvement
nodes.definition: recurring activity to enhance performance (3.52)

nodes.label: control
nodes.definition: measure that is modifying risk (3.61)
notes: Controls include any process (3.54), policy (3.53), device, practice, or other actions which modify risk (3.61). | It is possible that controls not always exert the intended or assumed modifying effect.

nodes.label: control objective
nodes.definition: statement describing what is to be achieved as a result of implementing controls (3.14)

nodes.label: correction
nodes.definition: action to eliminate a detected nonconformity (3.47)

nodes.label: corrective action
nodes.definition: action to eliminate the cause of a nonconformity (3.47) and to prevent recurrence

nodes.label: derived measure
nodes.definition: measure (3.42) that is defined as a function of two or more values of base measures (3.8)

nodes.label: documented information
nodes.definition: information required to be controlled and maintained by an organization (3.50) and the medium on which it is contained
notes: Documented information can be in any format and media and from any source. | Documented information can refer to: — the management system (3.41), including related processes (3.54); — information created in order for the organization (3.50) to operate (documentation); — evidence of results achieved (records).

nodes.label: effectiveness
nodes.definition: extent to which planned activities are realized and planned results achieved

nodes.label: event
nodes.definition: occurrence or change of a particular set of circumstances
notes: An event can be one or more occurrences, and can have several causes. | An event can consist of something not happening. | An event can sometimes be referred to as an "incident" or "accident".

nodes.label: external context
nodes.definition: external environment in which the organization seeks to achieve its objectives (3.49)
notes: External context can include the following: — the cultural, social, political, legal, regulatory, financial, technological, economic, natural and competitive environment, whether international, national, regional or local; — key drivers and trends having impact on the objectives of the organization (3.50); — relationships with, and perceptions and values of, external stakeholders (3.37).

nodes.label: governance of information security
nodes.definition: system by which an organization's (3.50) information security (3.28) activities are directed and controlled

nodes.label: governing body
nodes.definition: person or group of people who are accountable for the performance (3.52) and conformity of the organization (3.50)
notes: The governing body can, in some jurisdictions, be a board of directors.

nodes.label: indicator
nodes.definition: measure (3.42) that provides an estimate or evaluation

nodes.label: information need
nodes.definition: insight necessary to manage objectives (3.49), goals, risks and problems

nodes.label: information processing facilities
nodes.definition: any information processing system, service or infrastructure, or the physical location housing it

nodes.label: information security
nodes.definition: preservation of confidentiality (3.10), integrity (3.36) and availability (3.7) of information
notes: In addition, other properties, such as authenticity (3.6), accountability, non-repudiation (3.48), and reliability (3.55) can also be involved.

nodes.label: information security continuity
nodes.definition: processes (3.54) and procedures for ensuring continued information security (3.28) operations

nodes.label: information security event
nodes.definition: identified occurrence of a system, service or network state indicating a possible breach of information security (3.28) policy (3.53) or failure of controls (3.14), or a previously unknown situation that can be security relevant

nodes.label: information security incident
nodes.definition: single or a series of unwanted or unexpected information security events (3.30) that have a significant probability of compromising business operations and threatening information security (3.28)

nodes.label: information security incident management
nodes.definition: set of processes (3.54) for detecting, reporting, assessing, responding to, dealing with, and learning from information security incidents (3.31)

nodes.label: information security management system (ISMS) professional
nodes.definition: person who establishes, implements, maintains and continuously improves one or more information security management system processes (3.54)

nodes.label: information sharing community
nodes.definition: group of organizations (3.50) that agree to share information
notes: An organization can be an individual.

nodes.label: information system
nodes.definition: set of applications, services, information technology assets, or other information-handling components

nodes.label: integrity
nodes.definition: property of accuracy and completeness

nodes.label: interested party (preferred term) / stakeholder (admitted term)
nodes.definition: person or organization (3.50) that can affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a decision or activity

nodes.label: internal context
nodes.definition: internal environment in which the organization (3.50) seeks to achieve its objectives
notes: Internal context can include: — governance, organizational structure, roles and accountabilities; — policies (3.53), objectives (3.49), and the strategies that are in place to achieve them; — the capabilities, understood in terms of resources and knowledge (e.g. capital, time, people, processes (3.54), systems and technologies); — information systems (3.35), information flows and decision-making processes (both formal and informal); — relationships with, and perceptions and values of, internal stakeholders (3.37); — the organization's culture; — standards, guidelines and models adopted by the organization; — form and extent of contractual relationships.

nodes.label: level of risk
nodes.definition: magnitude of a risk (3.61) expressed in terms of the combination of consequences (3.12) and their likelihood (3.40)

nodes.label: likelihood
nodes.definition: chance of something happening

nodes.label: management system
nodes.definition: set of interrelated or interacting elements of an organization (3.50) to establish policies (3.53) and objectives (3.49) and processes (3.54) to achieve those objectives
notes: A management system can address a single discipline or several disciplines. | The system elements include the organization's structure, roles and responsibilities, planning and operation. | The scope of a management system may include the whole of the organization, specific and identified functions of the organization, specific and identified sections of the organization, or one or more functions across a group of organizations.

nodes.label: measure
nodes.definition: variable to which a value is assigned as the result of measurement (3.43)

nodes.label: measurement
nodes.definition: process (3.54) to determine a value

nodes.label: measurement function
nodes.definition: algorithm or calculation performed to combine two or more base measures (3.8)

nodes.label: measurement method
nodes.definition: logical sequence of operations, described generically, used in quantifying an attribute with respect to a specified scale
notes: The type of measurement method depends on the nature of the operations used to quantify an attribute (3.4). Two types can be distinguished: — subjective: quantification involving human judgment; and — objective: quantification based on numerical rules.

nodes.label: monitoring
nodes.definition: determining the status of a system, a process (3.54) or an activity
notes: To determine the status, there may be a need to check, supervise or critically observe.

nodes.label: nonconformity
nodes.definition: non-fulfilment of a requirement (3.56)

nodes.label: non-repudiation
nodes.definition: ability to prove the occurrence of a claimed event (3.21) or action and its originating entities

nodes.label: objective
nodes.definition: result to be achieved
notes: An objective can be strategic, tactical, or operational. | Objectives can relate to different disciplines (such as financial, health and safety, and environmental goals) and can apply at different levels [such as strategic, organization-wide, project, product and process (3.54)]. | An objective can be expressed in other ways, e.g. as an intended outcome, a purpose, an operational criterion, as an information security objective or by the use of other words with similar meaning (e.g. aim, goal, or target). | In the context of information security management systems, information security objectives are set by the organization, consistent with the information security policy, to achieve specific results.

nodes.label: organization
nodes.definition: person or group of people that has its own functions with responsibilities, authorities and relationships to achieve its objectives (3.49)
notes: The concept of organization includes but is not limited to sole-trader, company, corporation, firm, enterprise, authority, partnership, charity or institution, or part or combination thereof, whether incorporated or not, public or private.

nodes.label: outsource
nodes.definition: make an arrangement where an external organization (3.50) performs part of an organization's function or process (3.54)
notes: An external organization is outside the scope of the management system (3.41), although the outsourced function or process is within the scope.

nodes.label: performance
nodes.definition: measurable result
notes: Performance can relate either to quantitative or qualitative findings. | Performance can relate to the management of activities, processes (3.54), products (including services), systems or organizations (3.50).

nodes.label: policy
nodes.definition: intentions and direction of an organization (3.50), as formally expressed by its top management (3.75)

nodes.label: process
nodes.definition: set of interrelated or interacting activities which transforms inputs into outputs

nodes.label: reliability
nodes.definition: property of consistent intended behaviour and results

nodes.label: requirement
nodes.definition: need or expectation that is stated, generally implied or obligatory
notes: "Generally implied" means that it is custom or common practice for the organization and interested parties that the need or expectation under consideration is implied. | A specified requirement is one that is stated, for example in documented information.

nodes.label: residual risk
nodes.definition: risk (3.61) remaining after risk treatment (3.72)
notes: Residual risk can contain unidentified risk. | Residual risk can also be referred to as "retained risk".

nodes.label: review
nodes.definition: activity undertaken to determine the suitability, adequacy and effectiveness (3.20) of the subject matter to achieve established objectives (3.49)

nodes.label: review object
nodes.definition: specific item being reviewed

nodes.label: review objective
nodes.definition: statement describing what is to be achieved as a result of a review (3.59)

nodes.label: risk
nodes.definition: effect of uncertainty on objectives (3.49)
notes: An effect is a deviation from the expected — positive or negative. | Uncertainty is the state, even partial, of deficiency of information related to, understanding or knowledge of, an event, its consequence, or likelihood. | Risk is often characterized by reference to potential "events" (as defined in ISO Guide 73:2009, 3.5.1.3) and "consequences" (as defined in ISO Guide 73:2009, 3.6.1.3), or a combination of these. | Risk is often expressed in terms of a combination of the consequences of an event (including changes in circumstances) and the associated "likelihood" (as defined in ISO Guide 73:2009, 3.6.1.1) of occurrence. | In the context of information security management systems, information security risks can be expressed as effect of uncertainty on information security objectives. | Information security risk is associated with the potential that threats will exploit vulnerabilities of an information asset or group of information assets and thereby cause harm to an organization.

nodes.label: risk acceptance
nodes.definition: informed decision to take a particular risk (3.61)
notes: Risk acceptance can occur without risk treatment (3.72) or during the process (3.54) of risk treatment. | Accepted risks are subject to monitoring (3.46) and review (3.58).

nodes.label: risk analysis
nodes.definition: process (3.54) to comprehend the nature of risk (3.61) and to determine the level of risk (3.39)
notes: Risk analysis provides the basis for risk evaluation (3.67) and decisions about risk treatment (3.72). | Risk analysis includes risk estimation.

nodes.label: risk assessment
nodes.definition: overall process (3.54) of risk identification (3.68), risk analysis (3.63) and risk evaluation (3.67)

nodes.label: risk communication and consultation
nodes.definition: set of continual and iterative processes (3.54) that an organization conducts to provide, share or obtain information, and to engage in dialogue with stakeholders (3.37) regarding the management of risk (3.61)
notes: The information can relate to the existence, nature, form, likelihood (3.41), significance, evaluation, acceptability and treatment of risk. | Consultation is a two-way process of informed communication between an organization (3.50) and its stakeholders on an issue prior to making a decision or determining a direction on that issue. Consultation is: — a process which impacts on a decision through influence rather than power; and — an input to decision making, not joint decision making.

nodes.label: risk criteria
nodes.definition: terms of reference against which the significance of risk (3.61) is evaluated
notes: Risk criteria are based on organizational objectives, and external context (3.22) and internal context (3.38). | Risk criteria can be derived from standards, laws, policies (3.53) and other requirements (3.56).

nodes.label: risk evaluation
nodes.definition: process (3.54) of comparing the results of risk analysis (3.63) with risk criteria (3.66) to determine whether the risk (3.61) and/or its magnitude is acceptable or tolerable
notes: Risk evaluation assists in the decision about risk treatment (3.72).

nodes.label: risk identification
nodes.definition: process (3.54) of finding, recognizing and describing risks (3.61)
notes: Risk identification involves the identification of risk sources, events (3.21), their causes and their potential consequences (3.12). | Risk identification can involve historical data, theoretical analysis, informed and expert opinions, and stakeholders' (3.37) needs.

nodes.label: risk management
nodes.definition: coordinated activities to direct and control an organization (3.50) with regard to risk (3.61)

nodes.label: risk management process
nodes.definition: systematic application of management policies (3.53), procedures and practices to the activities of communicating, consulting, establishing the context and identifying, analysing, evaluating, treating, monitoring and reviewing risk (3.61)
notes: ISO/IEC 27005 uses the term "process" (3.54) to describe risk management overall. The elements within the risk management (3.69) process are referred to as "activities".

nodes.label: risk owner
nodes.definition: person or entity with the accountability and authority to manage a risk (3.61)

nodes.label: risk treatment
nodes.definition: process (3.54) to modify risk (3.61)
notes: Risk treatment can involve: — avoiding the risk by deciding not to start or continue with the activity that gives rise to the risk; — taking or increasing risk in order to pursue an opportunity; — removing the risk source; — changing the likelihood (3.40); — changing the consequences (3.12); — sharing the risk with another party or parties (including contracts and risk financing); — retaining the risk by informed choice. | Risk treatments that deal with negative consequences are sometimes referred to as "risk mitigation", "risk elimination", "risk prevention" and "risk reduction". | Risk treatment can create new risks or modify existing risks.

nodes.label: security implementation standard
nodes.definition: document specifying authorized ways for realizing security

nodes.label: threat
nodes.definition: potential cause of an unwanted incident, which can result in harm to a system or organization (3.50)

nodes.label: top management
nodes.definition: person or group of people who directs and controls an organization (3.50) at the highest level
notes: Top management has the power to delegate authority and provide resources within the organization. | If the scope of the management system (3.41) covers only part of an organization, then top management refers to those who direct and control that part of the organization. | Top management is sometimes called executive management and can include Chief Executive Officers, Chief Financial Officers, Chief Information Officers, and similar roles.

nodes.label: trusted information communication entity
nodes.definition: autonomous organization (3.50) supporting information exchange within an information sharing community (3.34)

nodes.label: vulnerability
nodes.definition: weakness of an asset or control (3.14) that can be exploited by one or more threats (3.74)
